subject: Law
statement_full_text: My work experience with both a chartered quantity surveyor and law firm Adam Benedict, was incredibly insightful as it allowed me to witness the process that goes into construction law from both professions, and the communication between the two that arises from this. The trainee solicitor I was shadowing taught me that a part of law is being able to quickly analyse and conclude cases - a majority of it is simply reading information from clients. One of the tasks I was set was to read through a file and make note of any important dates and summarise the argument from the Claimant. In order to improve my analysis and active reading skills, I entered a Caius Explore competition for English and attempted the reading technique, practical criticism. This experience was valuable to me as it pushed me to be patient and learn to appreciate the uncertainties of it, but it also allowed me to develop arguments based on the text and my thoughts alone; without the influence of context. This task forced me to read with purpose and constantly question the text whilst reading, further strengthening my analysis skills. Furthermore, at my school I act as a Senior Reading Ambassador which aims to help and improve the comprehension skills of younger students that perhaps struggle with reading, or are unable to practice this at home. Originally, I applied in order to improve my confidence and public speaking; whilst this position did help me accomplish this, it also improved my communicative skills as I work closely with a group of students and teachers, and suggested implementing a reward system in order to encourage pupils.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My work experience with both a chartered quantity surveyor and law firm Adam Benedict, was incredibly insightful as it allowed me to witness the process that goes into construction law from both professions, and the communication between the two that arises from this.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a wordy sentence that could be more succinct. You should find a way to shorten it without changing the meaning - the tutor suggests cutting about 6-7 words.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense the sentence by removing unnecessary words while maintaining the same meaning about witnessing construction law from both professions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The trainee solicitor I was shadowing taught me that a part of law is being able to quickly analyse and conclude cases - a majority of it is simply reading information from clients.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The phrase 'quickly analyse and conclude cases' doesn't mean much and doesn't work well as a summary. The pronoun usage is confusing, and saying 'a majority of it is simply reading information from clients' doesn't sound great - it makes law sound uninteresting. Universities want to see you're interested in the study of law, not just the mechanical tasks.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of vague summaries, reference a specific case you witnessed. Say something like 'One case I witnessed was [specific case], and they had to analyse [details], and this was the conclusion, and this was really interesting to me.' Make it more concrete and academic.

feedback_items.weak_passage: a majority of it is simply reading information from clients
feedback_items.your_feedback: This statement makes law sound uninteresting and doesn't put you in the best light. Although reading client information is what lawyers do, universities want to see interest in the study of law itself, not just administrative tasks.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this part entirely and focus on more academic aspects of law that demonstrate intellectual engagement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The work experience is good, but it needs to be linked back to something more academic. You should discuss an actual case, a real-world thing, and give your thoughts on it. That's what will really make you stand out.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reference a specific case you encountered during work experience and provide your analysis or thoughts on it to demonstrate academic engagement with law.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In order to improve my analysis and active reading skills, I entered a Caius Explore competition
feedback_items.your_feedback: The phrase 'in order to improve my analysis and active reading skills' isn't particularly necessary. You can just say you entered the competition without the preamble about why.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the explanatory phrase and simply state that you entered the competition.

feedback_items.weak_passage: attempted the reading technique, practical criticism
feedback_items.your_feedback: This doesn't make sense grammatically or just in general. You need to double check what you mean by this phrasing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what you mean by 'attempted the reading technique, practical criticism' - the grammar and meaning are unclear.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience was valuable to me as it pushed me to be patient and learn to appreciate the uncertainties of it, but it also allowed me to develop arguments based on the text and my thoughts alone; without the influence of context.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is anecdotal reflection that's too vague and general. If you're going to explain every step of how your thoughts developed, then use actual material. Don't talk in vague general terms - it's both uninteresting and hard to understand, believe, and follow because there's no evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of vague reflection, specify what arguments you developed and how. Use actual material from the competition to demonstrate your analytical thinking.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This task forced me to read with purpose and constantly question the text whilst reading, further strengthening my analysis skills.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Instead of just saying you strengthened your skills, you need to show proof. You could say 'From here, I applied these skills to reading a law case or reading an academic article' and then reference a specific source. This creates a more complete story than just claiming you can do things without evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Apply these skills to a specific law case or academic article. Search for a law article and say something like 'I was able to conclude [specific insights] because of my experiences in the Caius Explore competition.' This provides concrete evidence of skill development.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Furthermore, at my school I act as a Senior Reading Ambassador which aims to help and improve the comprehension skills of younger students that perhaps struggle with reading, or are unable to practice this at home. Originally, I applied in order to improve my confidence and public speaking; whilst this position did help me accomplish this, it also improved my communicative skills as I work closely with a group of students and teachers, and suggested implementing a reward system in order to encourage pupils.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire section is probably the point to cut. If you expand the other two points with more academic content as suggested, you won't need this. It's too general now, and having it alongside the Caius stuff takes up too much space. The rest isn't that relevant to law, so it's not useful for your statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either cut this section entirely or condense it to one sentence: 'I also am a Senior Reading Ambassador, helping younger students improve their reading skills.' The tutor suggests asking your teacher to include this in your reference instead if possible.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You have more than enough experiences for Question 3 - the law firm work, Caius Explore competition, and Senior Reading Ambassador are all good. However, the points you've pulled from these experiences aren't strong enough. You need more academic depth and specific examples.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on making the law firm and Caius experiences more academically robust with specific cases, articles, and concrete examples. Consider cutting or drastically condensing the Reading Ambassador section to make room.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
I have always been fascinated by Economics and I realised my interest when doing some basic reading on the subject in the beginning of Year 9. I was sceptical of capitalism and sought a more balanced perspective on the matter by reading the Liberal Manifesto. In doing so I became more convinced that market economies and free trade are critical in reducing poverty and sparking growth globally. In his manifesto, it is said that Socialism is ultimately incompatible with democracy, which is an argument that is echoed by Friedman in Capitalism and Freedom. However, I feel like there is a false dichotomy implied when it comes to thinking about these systems. In reality, governments can play a complementary role to the markets by intervening and providing merit goods, such as healthcare. Friedman rejects this notion, and Norberg overlooks the limitations of this approach, as economics is ultimately about trade-offs.

Second, I took a "metrics" Master Class on regression from Imperial College London, where I looked at the relationship between Gross Capital Formation and gross GDP, which helped me understand the relationship between savings, investment, and growth by using real world data. Then, I read "Animal Spirits" which emphasises how psychology and human error play a bigger role in markets than neoclassical economics might suggest, especially after the Great Financial Crisis. In contrast, the neoliberals don't believe that psychology is a factor in economics. I concluded that such forces justify greater government intervention. For my EPQ, I investigated the relationship between housing estates and violent crime within London Boroughs. I conducted literature reviews in order to find variables that could impact crime, including population density, employment, inequality, amongst other factors. Additionally, I gained an insight into how to use statistical software, R, and excel for multivariate data analysis.

Additionally, I explored the connection between economics and politics by taking a Yale lecture series on liberalism, showing the evolution of political philosophy from Locke to Rawls, which has given me a broader understanding of the relationship between politics and economics in liberal societies. Witnessing this evolution has given me greater understanding of the role of rights, justice, and governance in economic policy. I read Fukuyama's Liberalism and its Discontents, which argues that political populism both left and right stems from the loss of trust in democratic institutions. This is especially interesting as populism challenges the efficiency of markets and restricts free trade, which are both pivotal concepts in economics.

Third, outside of academia, I was the captain of my football team for 3 years, leading training sessions and organising fixtures. This helped improve my leadership and organisational skills. I also play the Violin and am working towards my grade 8 exam, which has been challenging but rewarding, teaching me discipline and patience through consistent practice. I completed my Duke of Edinburgh Bronze, Silver, and Gold awards which required teamwork, resilience, and perseverance through difficult expeditions. Moreover, I completed a 6 month long school mentor program, mentoring younger students. These experiences have allowed me to develop important life skills such as responsibility, empathy, and the ability to work well with others.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have always been fascinated by Economics and I realised my interest when doing some basic reading on the subject in the beginning of Year 9.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This opening is terrible - it's the most generic opening possible for any personal statement. It adds nothing and wastes valuable space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence entirely and start with something substantive about your actual engagement with economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was sceptical of capitalism
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not condescending, but based on nothing you've done until this point, you probably don't have a good understanding of what capitalism actually is. To say you're sceptical of capitalism as a whole is a strong stance when you're not going to back it up, and you definitely don't back it up. You could say you're sceptical of parts of it or some areas, but being sceptical of capitalism entirely without substantiation doesn't work.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be more specific about what aspects of capitalism you were skeptical about, or remove this vague claim entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I became more convinced that market economies and free trade are critical in reducing poverty and sparking growth globally.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't explain how you became convinced of this or what the link is between market economies and poverty reduction. It's just stated without development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain the reasoning or evidence that convinced you, providing specific examples or arguments from your reading.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In his manifesto, it is said that Socialism is ultimately incompatible with democracy, which is an argument that is echoed by Friedman in Capitalism and Freedom.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This seems quite obvious and then you name drop Friedman with no development of his ideas whatsoever.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop Friedman's actual arguments in detail or remove the name drop. Don't just cite sources without engaging with their content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, I feel like there is a false dichotomy implied when it comes to thinking about these systems. In reality, governments can play a complementary role to the markets by intervening and providing merit goods, such as healthcare. Friedman rejects this notion, and Norberg overlooks the limitations of this approach
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've mentioned three fantastic sources (Liberal Manifesto, Friedman, Norberg) but provided nothing from any of them - only your own thoughts and opinions. The statement about government intervention and merit goods is A-level basic - the first thing you learn about market failures. To say Friedman rejects something so broad is not right, and these authors aren't discussing at length such basic statements because they know it's much more complex.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Actually engage with what Friedman and Norberg specifically argue. Provide their detailed positions rather than oversimplified claims. Show deeper understanding beyond A-level basics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: economics is ultimately about trade-offs
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just your own thought at the end with no development. It's a basic observation.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this idea with specific examples of trade-offs or remove it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I took a "metrics" Master Class on regression from Imperial College London, where I looked at the relationship between Gross Capital Formation and gross GDP
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is way too simple. You cannot say you took a metrics masterclass and then that was what you came up with. You need to be a lot more detailed in what you actually did if you're going to even bother mentioning it. This would actually be a red flag, especially for LSE.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide significantly more detail about your methodology, findings, and analysis from the masterclass, or choose a different topic to discuss entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Then, I read "Animal Spirits" which emphasises how psychology and human error play a bigger role in markets than neoclassical economics might suggest, especially after the Great Financial Crisis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just summarizing and saying psychology and human error in markets exists - it's like saying the grass is green. What have you actually talked about from this book apart from the most basic observation?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Discuss specific insights, arguments, or examples from Animal Spirits rather than just stating the obvious conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In contrast, the neoliberals don't believe that psychology is a factor in economics. I concluded that such forces justify greater government intervention.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is way too sweeping a statement about neoliberals. If you're going to discuss government intervention in an economic sense, use proper jargon and actual terminology.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be specific about which neoliberal economists and what they actually argue. Use proper economic terminology when discussing intervention.

feedback_items.weak_passage: For my EPQ, I investigated the relationship between housing estates and violent crime within London Boroughs. I conducted literature reviews in order to find variables that could impact crime, including population density, employment, inequality, amongst other factors. Additionally, I gained an insight into how to use statistical software, R, and excel for multivariate data analysis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your EPQ is well underexplained. Take 3-4 sentences to walk through your EPQ properly and say what you found, what was really interesting, where you developed it from, what you read, and your reasoning. That's the level we're looking for. Then connect it to something like Animal Spirits by saying how you could have modeled it differently based on that reading.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand significantly: explain your findings, interesting discoveries, your development process, what you read, and your reasoning. Then connect it to your wider reading like Animal Spirits to show how you'd approach the modeling differently.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I explored the connection between economics and politics by taking a Yale lecture series on liberalism, showing the evolution of political philosophy from Locke to Rawls, which has given me a broader understanding of the relationship between politics and economics in liberal societies. Witnessing this evolution has given me greater understanding of the role of rights, justice, and governance in economic policy.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've got a Yale lecture series and all you say about it is that liberalism has evolved from Locke to Rawls, apparently. You mention witnessing this evolution gave you skills, but there's no actual content from the lectures. It's name dropping without substance.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Discuss specific arguments, concepts, or insights from the Yale lectures. What exactly did you learn about the evolution of political philosophy and its economic implications?

feedback_items.weak_passage: I read Fukuyama's Liberalism and its Discontents, which argues that political populism both left and right stems from the loss of trust in democratic institutions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mention Fukuyama but none of it is actually explained - just a basic summary with no development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Engage with Fukuyama's actual arguments in depth rather than providing a one-sentence summary.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This is especially interesting as populism challenges the efficiency of markets and restricts free trade, which are both pivotal concepts in economics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just name dropping big ideas - Earth is flat/Earth is round type level of ideas - and not really expanding on them.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop your analysis of populism's economic effects with specific examples and detailed reasoning.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Third, outside of academia, I was the captain of my football team for 3 years, leading training sessions and organising fixtures. This helped improve my leadership and organisational skills. I also play the Violin and am working towards my grade 8 exam, which has been challenging but rewarding, teaching me discipline and patience through consistent practice. I completed my Duke of Edinburgh Bronze, Silver, and Gold awards which required teamwork, resilience, and perseverance through difficult expeditions. Moreover, I completed a 6 month long school mentor program, mentoring younger students. These experiences have allowed me to develop important life skills such as responsibility, empathy, and the ability to work well with others.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor knows that no matter how many times they tell students not to include this kind of stuff, students won't listen. They think it's a bit of a waste of space but acknowledge students will include it anyway.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you can get this into your reference instead, do that. The tutor personally would not include this section but acknowledges it's the student's choice.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The statement is jumping around too much and just name dropping everything. You've read fantastic texts - Liberal Manifesto, Friedman, Norberg, Animal Spirits, Yale lectures, Fukuyama - and done impressive supercurricular work. But you're not including any of the actual good stuff from these sources in your statement. It looks like you've done all that work but aren't making use of it, which is actually sad.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For each source you mention, include specific arguments, insights, or content from that source. Develop your points fully rather than just listing what you've read. Show you've actually engaged with the material deeply.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor respects you a lot for having gone through all these texts and having done all these things - it's so impressive, all the actual extra supercurricular reading. The unfortunate thing is you're not including any of that good stuff in your statement. The important work is done; you just need to clean up sections and make them fully developed at points.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: You don't need to do 20 more hours of work or go away and read more. Just take the reading you've already done and actually discuss the content in detail. Make complete sections with full development of ideas.

feedback_items.your_feedback: No statement text was provided in the document. The feedback section indicates this is for a PPE application, but the actual personal statement content is missing from the batch file.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Submit the complete personal statement for review.

feedback_items.your_feedback: No statement text was provided in the document. The feedback section indicates this is for a PPE application, but the actual personal statement content is missing from the batch file.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Submit the complete personal statement for review.

feedback_items.your_feedback: No statement text was provided in the document. The feedback section indicates this is for a PPE application, but the actual personal statement content is missing from the batch file.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Submit the complete personal statement for review.
